title: Acute Limb Ischemia
diagnosis_topic: Sudden arterial occlusion leading to limb ischemia
setup_script: A 65-year-old woman with a history of atrial fibrillation and hypertension presents with sudden onset of severe pain, pallor and numbness in her right leg that started 4 hours ago. She reports no history of trauma. She is on warfarin but admits to missing doses. Her medications include metoprolol and lisinopril.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks for vital signs
dynamic_flow.reply: BP 130/75 mmHg, HR 95 bpm irregularly irregular, RR 18/min, Temp 36.8 C, SpO2 97% on RA.
Right leg is cool and pale with mottling to mid-calf, capillary refill >4 sec, no Doppler signals distally, sensation diminished, motor weakness present.
CBC normal, BMP normal, INR 1.4, lactate 3.2 mmol/L.
Bedside Doppler confirms absent arterial flow, duplex ultrasound shows acute occlusion of the common femoral artery.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident initiates systemic anticoagulation with heparin
dynamic_flow.reply: Pain stabilizes but motor deficit remains.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident consults vascular surgery and plans emergent revascularization
dynamic_flow.reply: Proceed to OR for embolectomy or catheter-directed thrombolysis depending on limb viability.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident hesitates to act or delays therapy
dynamic_flow.reply: Limb becomes mottled with fixed staining; patient reports worsening numbness indicating impending necrosis.
Explain that atrial fibrillation predisposes to emboli; other causes include in situ thrombosis and trauma.
Monitor for reperfusion injury, compartment syndrome; continue anticoagulation and evaluate for underlying cardiac source.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about imaging alternatives
dynamic_flow.reply: CT angiography can define anatomy but should not delay intervention.
Pain, pallor, pulselessness, paresthesia, poikilothermia, paralysis confirm severity.
Indicated if compartment pressures rise after reperfusion.

critical_decision_points: Rapid recognition of acute limb ischemia and six P's
Choice of imaging without delaying therapy
Appropriate selection of embolectomy vs. thrombolysis
Monitoring for and management of reperfusion injury and compartment syndrome
